column2: We enjoyed the fun of it, said the artist modestly, "and as for the model, it was a welcome variation on posing for hours for 'The Lost Hylas'."
column3: We enjoyed the fun of it, said the artist modestly, "and as for the model, it was a welcome variation on posing for hours for 'The Lost Hylas'."

column2: Demosthenes Platterbaff, the eminent Unrest Inducer, stood on his trial for a serious offence, and the eyes of the political world were focussed on the jury.
column3: Demosthenes Platterbaff, the eminent Unrest Inducer, stood on his trial for a serious offence, and the eyes of the political world were focussed on the jury.

column2: The offence, it should be stated, was serious for the Government rather than for the prisoner.
column3: The offence, it should be stated, was serious for the Government rather than for the prisoner.

column2: He had blown up the Albert Hall on the eve of the great Liberal Federation Tango Tea, the occasion on which the Chancellor of the Exchequer was expected to propound his new theory: "Do partridges spread infectious diseases?" Platterbaff had chosen his time well; the Tango Tea had been hurriedly postponed, but there were other political fixtures which could not be put off under any circumstances.
column3: He had blown up the Albert Hall on the eve of the great Liberal Federation Tango Tea, the occasion on which the Chancellor of the Exchequer was expected to propound his new theory: "Do partridges spread infectious diseases?" Platterbaff had chosen his time well; the Tango Tea had been hurriedly postponed, but there were other political fixtures which could not be put off under any circumstances.

column2: The day after the trial there was to be a by-election at Nemesis-on-Hand, and it had been openly announced in the division that if Platterbaff were languishing in gaol on polling day the Government candidate would be "outed" to a certainty.
column3: The day after the trial there was to be a by-election at Nemesis on Hand, and it had been openly announced in the division that if Platterbaff were languishing in gaol on polling day the Government candidate would be "outed" to a certainty.

column2: Unfortunately, there could be no doubt or misconception as to Platterbaff's guilt.
column3: Unfortunately, there could be no doubt or misconception as to Platterbaff's guilt.

column2: He had not only pleaded guilty, but had expressed his intention of repeating his escapade in other directions as soon as circumstances permitted; throughout the trial he was busy examining a small model of the Free Trade Hall in Manchester.
column3: He had not only pleaded guilty, but had expressed his intention of repeating his escapade in other directions as soon as circumstances permitted; throughout the trial he was busy examining a small model of the Free Trade Hall in Manchester.

column2: The jury could not possibly find that the prisoner had not deliberately and intentionally blown up the Albert Hall; the question was: Could they find any extenuating circumstances which would permit of an acquittal?
column3: The jury could not possibly find that the prisoner had not deliberately and intentionally blown up the Albert Hall; the question was: Could they find any extenuating circumstances which would permit of an acquittal?

column2: Of course any sentence which the law might feel compelled to inflict would be followed by an immediate pardon, but it was highly desirable, from the Government's point of view, that the necessity for such an exercise of clemency should not arise.
column3: Of course any sentence which the law might feel compelled to inflict would be followed by an immediate pardon, but it was highly desirable, from the Government's point of view, that the necessity for such an exercise of clemency should not arise.

column2: A headlong pardon, on the eve of a bye-election, with threats of a heavy voting defection if it were withheld or even delayed, would not necessarily be a surrender, but it would look like one.
column3: A headlong pardon, on the eve of a bye election, with threats of a heavy voting defection if it were withheld or even delayed, would not necessarily be a surrender, but it would look like one.

column2: Opponents would be only too ready to attribute ungenerous motives.
column3: Opponents would be only too ready to attribute ungenerous motives.

column2: Hence the anxiety in the crowded Court, and in the little groups gathered round the tape-machines in Whitehall and Downing Street and other affected centres.
column3: Hence the anxiety in the crowded Court, and in the little groups gathered round the tape machines in Whitehall and Downing Street and other affected centres.

column2: The jury returned from considering their verdict; there was a flutter, an excited murmur, a deathlike hush.
column3: The jury returned from considering their verdict; there was a flutter, an excited murmur, a deathlike hush.

column2: The foreman delivered his message:
column3: The foreman delivered his message:

column2: The jury find the prisoner guilty of blowing up the Albert Hall.	The jury find the prisoner guilty of blowing up the Albert Hall.

column2: The jury wish to add a rider drawing attention to the fact that a by-election is pending in the Parliamentary division of Nemesis-on-Hand."
column3: The jury wish to add a rider drawing attention to the fact that a by-election is pending in the Parliamentary division of Nemesis on Hand."

column2: That, of course, said the Government Prosecutor, springing to his feet, "is equivalent to an acquittal?"
column3: That, of course, said the Government Prosecutor, springing to his feet, "is equivalent to an acquittal?"

column2: I hardly think so, said the Judge, coldly; "I feel obliged to sentence the prisoner to a week's imprisonment."
column3: I hardly think so, said the Judge, coldly; "I feel obliged to sentence the prisoner to a week's imprisonment."

column2: And may the Lord have mercy on the poll, a Junior Counsel exclaimed irreverently.
column3: And may the Lord have mercy on the poll, a Junior Counsel exclaimed irreverently.

column2: It was a scandalous sentence, but then the Judge was not on the Ministerial side in politics.
column3: It was a scandalous sentence, but then the Judge was not on the Ministerial side in politics.

column2: The verdict and sentence were made known to the public at twenty minutes past five in the afternoon; at half-past five a dense crowd was massed outside the Prime Minister's residence lustily singing, to the air of "Trelawney":
column3: The verdict and sentence were made known to the public at twenty minutes past five in the afternoon; at half past five a dense crowd was massed outside the Prime Minister's residence lustily singing, to the air of "Trelawney":

column2: And should our Hero rot in gaol, For e'en a single day, There's Fifteen Hundred Voting Men Will vote the other way.
column3: And should our Hero rot in gaol, For e'en a single day, There's Fifteen Hundred Voting Men Will vote the other way.

column2: Fifteen hundred, said the Prime Minister, with a shudder; "it's too horrible to think of.
column3: Fifteen hundred, said the Prime Minister, with a shudder; "it's too horrible to think of.

column2: Our majority last time was only a thousand and seven."
column3: Our majority last time was only a thousand and seven."

column2: The poll opens at eight to-morrow morning, said the Chief Organiser; "we must have him out by 7 a.m."
column3: The poll opens at eight to morrow morning, said the Chief Organiser; "we must have him out by seven a m"

column2: Seven-thirty, amended the Prime Minister; "we must avoid any appearance of precipitancy."
column3: Seven thirty, amended the Prime Minister; "we must avoid any appearance of precipitancy."

column2: Not later than seven-thirty, then, said the Chief Organiser; "I have promised the agent down there that he shall be able to display posters announcing 'Platterbaff is Out,' before the poll opens.
column3: Not later than seven thirty, then, said the Chief Organiser; "I have promised the agent down there that he shall be able to display posters announcing 'Platterbaff is Out,' before the poll opens.

column2: He said it was our only chance of getting a telegram 'Radprop is In' to-night."
column3: He said it was our only chance of getting a telegram 'Radprop is In' to night."

column2: At half-past seven the next morning the Prime Minister and the Chief Organiser sat at breakfast, making a perfunctory meal, and awaiting the return of the Home Secretary, who had gone in person to superintend the releasing of Platterbaff.
column3: At half past seven the next morning the Prime Minister and the Chief Organiser sat at breakfast, making a perfunctory meal, and awaiting the return of the Home Secretary, who had gone in person to superintend the releasing of Platterbaff.

column2: Despite the earliness of the hour a small crowd had gathered in the street outside, and the horrible menacing Trelawney refrain of the "Fifteen Hundred Voting Men" came in a steady, monotonous chant.
column3: Despite the earliness of the hour a small crowd had gathered in the street outside, and the horrible menacing Trelawney refrain of the "Fifteen Hundred Voting Men" came in a steady, monotonous chant.

column2: They will cheer presently when they hear the news, said the Prime Minister hopefully; "hark!

column2: That must be McKenna."

column2: The Home Secretary entered the room a moment later, disaster written on his face.
column3: The Home Secretary entered the room a moment later, disaster written on his face.

column2: He won't go! he exclaimed.

column2: Won't leave gaol?"

column2: He says he never has left prison without a brass band to play him out, and he's not going to go without one now."
column3: He says he never has left prison without a brass band to play him out, and he's not going to go without one now."

column2: But surely that sort of thing is provided by his supporters and admirers? said the Prime Minister; "we can hardly be supposed to supply a released prisoner with a brass band.
column3: But surely that sort of thing is provided by his supporters and admirers? said the Prime Minister; "we can hardly be supposed to supply a released prisoner with a brass band.

column2: How on earth could we defend it on the Estimates?"
column3: How on earth could we defend it on the Estimates?"

column3: His supporters say it is up to us to provide the music, said the Home Secretary; "they say we put him in prison, and it's our affair to see that he leaves it in a respectable manner.

column2: Anyway, he won't go unless he has a band."

column2: Is Platterbaff out yet?

column2: This is not a moment for standing on dignity, he observed bluntly; "musicians must be supplied at once.
column3: This is not a moment for standing on dignity, he observed bluntly; "musicians must be supplied at once.

column2: Platterbaff must have his band."
column3: Platterbaff must have his band."

column2: The Prime Minister, the Home Secretary, the Chief Organiser, and several earnest helpful friends were gathered in the inner gateway of the prison, talking volubly to Demosthenes Platterbaff, who stood with folded arms and squarely planted feet, silent in their midst. Golden-tongued legislators whose eloquence had swayed the Marconi Inquiry Committee, or at any rate the greater part of it, expended their arts of oratory in vain on this stubborn unyielding man.
